authors: Chloe-Lee Longhetti For Daily Mail Australia
description: MKR's Courtney and Valerie make the grand final
title: MKR's Courtney and Valerie make the grand final
title_page: MKR's Courtney and Valerie make the grand final | Daily Mail Online
text:
The teams going into the My Kitchen Rules grand final have been revealed.
On the show on Wednesday, mother and daughter team Valerie and Courtney made the top two of the show, and will battle brother and sister duo Amy and Tyson for $250,000.
The news came after Valerie and Courtney sent Tim and Kyle packing, after a tense sudden-death showdown.
Scroll down for video
In it to win it! MKR's Courtney (R) cried as she and mother Valerie (L) made the grand final
'I'm just so proud,' Courtney said as she burst into tears.
She added to camera to her mother: 'You know who will be extra proud, is poppy,' referring to Valerie's father, who handed down a book of family recipes which they cook from in the competition.
Tim and Kyle meanwhile, were 'gutted' that they didn't make it through to the grand final.
Sorry boys! The news came after Valerie and Courtney sent Tim and Kyle packing, after a tense sudden-death showdown
'To come this close and not go to the big dance is disappointing,' Kyle said.
Tim added that they were still proud to have finished in third place on the show.
He commended Valerie and Courtney on making it through, saying: 'Congratulations, I'm stocked for you honestly, it's a great achievement.'
Tim and Kyle finished on a grand total score of 46, while the girls scored 50 points.
The boys served an entree of scallops with celeriac puree and pancetta, a main of confit duck with coffee pumpkin, and a dessert of brownie with chocolate stout mousse and coffee syrup.
It's on! Courtney and Valerie will battle Amy and Tyson (seen) for $250,000 in the grand final
Valerie and Courtney cooked an entree of peppered chicken livers with fennel and tomato chutney, a main of oxtail stew with pickled onion mash and eggplant kasundi, and a dessert of cardamom dumplings with saffron creme anglaise.
The girls were told by judge Colin Fassnidge that 'there was nothing bad I can say' about their entree.
Pete said it was a dish they would 'remember for a long time.'
They also had glowing reviews for their main, but fell short on their dessert.
Too sweet! The mother and daughter duo had glowing reviews for their main, but fell short on their dessert
Judge Karen Martini said the dumplings had a great texture, but she thought the anglaise was a little too thin.
Colin meanwhile, said the anglaise was 'way too sweet.'
Tim and Kyle were told their presentation for their entree was lacking, while they should have put more on the dish.
Pete Evans said: 'Kyle, I know you, if you were served that as a part of a three course meal, you would be disappointed.'
Pete said their main was a 'stellar dish.'
They also fell short on their dessert, with judge Guy Grossi saying he didn't enjoy the mousse, because the stout flavour was really strong.
The judges were also divided on the use of pretzels on their dessert, as they were just crushed from the packet.
